name: Psychology of Prejudice
long_desc: This course is devoted to the study of both traditional and more modern forms of prejudice and discrimination and the psychological processes that can arise from categorizations and stereotyping. The class provides an overview of the cognitive and emotional underpinnings of prejudice and discrimination as it pertains to many forms of inequality. Its goal is to examine social differences and social inequality in many areas of society. The psychological theories underlying these behaviors will be examined as well as their impact on the lives of stigmatized individuals. In addition to the traditional forms of prejudice based on such things as race, gender and age, other inequalities that result from less traditional groupings such as social class, appearance, and disability will be explored. Research on issues of social identity, intergroup relations and the reduction of prejudice will be examined through readings and class activities.

custom_fields.goals: Demonstrate an awareness of the biases individuals have that affect reasoning and decision making regarding others.Explain prejudice as a product of a range of factors since the development of prejudice is a function of individual differences, situational factors, and societal factors. Understanding each can aid in the quest to control the negative effects of prejudice and discrimination. Critically analyze and evaluate relevant research in the field of Social Psychology and gain an understanding of the types of research used to study prejudice at both an implicit and explicit level and to explore the strengths and weaknesses of each of these approaches.Understand the origins of prejudice, stereotyping, and intergroup rejection and its impact on the daily lives and experiences of the targets of such bias and apply various psychological theories that explain the existence of prejudice to these situations.Analyze group privilege such as White Privilege, male privilege and heterosexual privilege in order to identify group disparities and how group identity can determine ones experiences in society.Assess prejudice reduction techniques and programs that have been developed over the years to combat prejudice in its many forms to determine which techniques have been effective and why others have failed.
custom_fields.key_topics: Methods of studying prejudice and discrimination, Historical change in the nature and expression of prejudice and discrimination, Individual differences that are most closely linked to prejudice including personality traits, ideology, and situational causes, Major theories accounting for prejudice formation, The experience of prejudice by various subgroups in areas such as work experience, education, and healthcare, Methods of decreasing prejudice
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge:
85-241 Social Psychology

Students need to be familiar with reading research journal articles and have a sound understanding of research methodology.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Grades will be determined by performance on three essay style tests and a number of class papers, activities and assignments. Among the main assignments will be a 10 page literature review of a relevant prejudice-related topic and an analysis of selected research articles focusing on social stigmas. In addition all students will be responsible for presenting and critiquing readings and leading course discussion related to the reading.
custom_fields.relevance:
Dietrich GenEd Prior to Fall 2021: Deciding
Dietrich GenEd After Fall 2021: Equity and Justice

Understanding how both conscious and unconscious bias against groups can impact the experiences of stigmatized groups is useful in almost any area where such bias may exist. This course will not only provide insight into the reasons for the bias but will also provide students with tools to use to combat prejudice and discrimination at both a personal as well as social level.
custom_fields.learning_resources: Course readings will be posted on Canvas. We will also use a textbook, which will need to be purchased by students.
custom_fields.extra_time_commitment: There are no external time commitments for the course other than preparing for course presentations, which are done with partners.
